org.sbrubbles.conditio

Interface Scope

  • All Superinterfaces:
    AutoCloseable

    public interface Scope
extends AutoCloseable
    A scope is a resource which hosts this library's main machinery. They can be nested, creating a stack of scopes; the machinery is able to navigate this stack and search for the relevant objects.

    To ensure proper nesting, scopes have controlled creation and closing. As a consequence, createing a scope without closeing it will break this nesting. Use it only in a try-with-resources, and you'll be fine :)

    The core operation is signal, which is called when lower-level code doesn't know how to handle a condition. signal looks for something that can handle the given condition in the call stack, and this handler then chooses what to do, like aborting or looking for a recovery strategy (also known as a restart) and using it to provide a result.

    In practice, signal is quite low-level, and works better as a primitive operation. raise and notify provide better ergonomics, and should cover most use cases.

    Restarts only make sense for specific invocations. Therefore, they're set only when a condition is signalled, or when code calling a signalling method wraps that call with call to provide more restarts.

    Usage should look something like this: 

     try(Scope scope = Scopes.create()) {
   // establishing a new handler, which accepts MalformedEntry conditions and
   // delegates the work to a RetryWith-compatible restart
   scope.handle(MalformedEntry.class, (c, ops) -> ops.restart(new RetryWith("FAIL: " + c.getText())));

   // ...somewhere deeper in the call stack...
   try(Scope scope = Scopes.create()) {
     // signals a condition, sets a restart, and waits for the result
     Entry entry = scope.raise(new MalformedEntry("NOOOOOOOO"),
                      Restart.on(RetryWith.class, r -> func(r.getValue())));

     // carry on...
   }
 }

    • Method Detail

      • handle

        <C extends Condition,S extends C> Scope handle(Class<S> conditionType,
                                               BiFunction<C,Handler.Operations,Handler.Decision> body)
        Establishes a new handler in this scope. It is responsible for handling conditions, returning a result for signal.
        Type Parameters:
        C - a subtype of Condition.
        S - a subtype of C, so that body is still compatible with C but may accept subtypes other than S.
        Parameters:
        conditionType - the type of conditions handled.
        body - the handler code.
        Returns:
        this instance, for method chaining.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if one or both parameters are null.

      • call

        <T> T call(Supplier<T> body,
           Restart<?>... restarts)
        Evaluates body, providing additional restarts for it. It's useful for scopes that may not know how to handle a particular condition, but can provide recovery strategies for it, similarly to Common Lisp's restart-case.

        Usage example: 

         final Restart SKIP_ENTRY = Restart.on(SkipEntry.class, r -> SKIP_ENTRY_MARKER);

 for (String line : lines) {
   // parseLogEntry may signal a condition. This code doesn't handle it,
   // but it provides SKIP_ENTRY as one more possible restart
   Entry entry = scope.call(() -> parseLogEntry(line), SKIP_ENTRY);

   if (!SKIP_ENTRY_MARKER.equals(entry)) {
     entries.add(entry);
   }
 }
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type returned by body.
        Parameters:
        body - some code.
        restarts - some restarts, which will be available to all handlers above in the call stack.
        Returns:
        the result of calling body.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if at least one parameter is null.

      • signal

        <T> T signal(Condition condition,
             HandlerNotFoundPolicy<T> handlerNotFoundPolicy,
             Restart<T>... restarts)
      throws NullPointerException,
             HandlerNotFoundException,
             ClassCastException,
             AbortException
        Signals a situation which the currently running code doesn't know how to deal with. This method will search for a compatible handler and run it, interpreting the handler's decision (which is expected to be not null) and returning the end result.

        This method is a primitive operation. Common use cases can use other methods, with better ergonomics.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the expected type of the object to be returned.
        Parameters:
        condition - a condition, representing a situation which higher-level code will decide how to handle.
        handlerNotFoundPolicy - what to do if no handler is found.
        restarts - some restarts, which will be available to the eventual handler.
        Returns:
        the end result, as provided by the selected handler.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if one of the arguments, or the selected handler's decision is null.
        HandlerNotFoundException - if the policy opts to error out.
        ClassCastException - if the value provided by the handler isn't type-compatible with T.
        AbortException - if the eventual handler aborts execution.
        See Also:
        notify(Condition, Restart[]), raise(Condition, Restart[])

      • notify

        default void notify(Condition condition,
                    Restart<?>... restarts)
             throws NullPointerException,
                    AbortException
        Signals a condition which may go unhandled and returns no useful value. This method always provides a Resume restart.

        This method is a way to provide hints or notifications to higher-level code, which can be safely resumed and maybe trigger some useful side effects.

        Parameters:
        condition - a condition, which here acts as a notice that something happened.
        restarts - some restarts, which, along with Resume, will be available to the eventual handler.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if one of the arguments, or the selected handler's decision is null.
        AbortException - if the eventual handler aborts execution.

      • raise

        default <T> T raise(Condition condition,
                    Restart<T>... restarts)
             throws NullPointerException,
                    HandlerNotFoundException,
                    ClassCastException,
                    AbortException
        Signals a condition that must be handled and return a result. This method always provides a UseValue restart.
        Parameters:
        condition - a condition that must be handled.
        restarts - some restarts, which, along with UseValue, will be available to the eventual handler.
        Returns:
        the end result, as provided by the selected handler.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if one of the arguments, or the selected handler's decision is null.
        HandlerNotFoundException - if no available handler was able to handle this condition.
        ClassCastException - if the value provided by the handler isn't type-compatible with T.
        AbortException - if the eventual handler aborts execution.

      • getAllHandlers

        Iterable<Handler> getAllHandlers()
        An object to iterate over all reachable handlers in the call stack, starting from this instance to the root scope.
        Returns:
        an iterable to get all reachable handlers in the call stack.

      • getAllRestarts

        Iterable<Restart<?>> getAllRestarts()
        An object to iterate over all reachable restarts in the call stack, starting from this instance to the root scope.
        Returns:
        an iterable to get all reachable restarts in the call stack.

      • getParent

        Scope getParent()
        The Scope instance wrapping this one. May be null if this is the topmost Scope.
        Returns:
        the Scope instance wrapping this one, or null if this is a root scope.

      • close

        default void close()
        Updates the scope nesting when execution leaves the try block. Subtypes which override this should still call this method to preserve the proper nesting.
        Specified by:
        close in interface AutoCloseable
